pageData.text: The skin is made up of two main layers: a superficial <button class='glossary-text'>epidermis</button> and a deeper <button class='glossary-text'>dermis</button>. The epidermis is composed of epithelial tissue. This tissue is composed of sheets of tightly arranged cells with very little intercellular material that sit on top of a <button class='glossary-text'>basement membrane</button>. This membrane separates the epithelium from the connective tissue of the dermis. Deep to the dermis is the <button class='glossary-text'>hypodermis</button>, a supportive subcutaneous layer. Together, these layers provide protection from mechanical injuries, infection, and fluid loss.

pageData.text: Skin cancer is on the rise in the United States. It is estimated that one in five people will be diagnosed with skin cancer at some point in their lives. And around 5 million cases of basal and squamous cell skin cancers are diagnosed every year in the United States. Skin cancer doesn’t usually result in death; however, it is estimated that about 2,000 people die from it every year. Most of these deaths occur when patients don’t seek regular medical treatment and the cancerous growth has gotten too large for treatment to be effective.

Although most skin cancers are caused by prolonged sun exposure and repeated sunburns, melanoma can occur on skin that hasn't been exposed to the sun. Sometimes melanoma can be identified as dark lesions on palms, soles, fingertips, toes, or mucous membranes lining the mouth, nose, vagina, or anus. Other melanomas are associated with a bleeding or itchy mole that has changed shape, or a small lesion with irregular borders and portions that appear red, pink, white, blue, or blue-black. Checking the skin regularly for changes is important for the early detection of skin cancers, which in turn is key for treatments to be effective.

pageData.text: The integumentary system protects the body from the external environment and works with other body systems to regulate internal processes. Major structures include the skin, glands, hair, and nails. The main functions of the integumentary system are protection, regulation, and sensation.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Integumentary System

pageData.subTitle: Skin
pageData.text: Skin is the largest and fastest-growing organ in the body. The outermost layer, the <button class='glossary-text'>epidermis</button>, is composed of stratified squamous epithelial tissue. Below this layer is the <button class='glossary-text'>dermis</button>, which contains the cutaneous  glands, hair follicles, and most of the skin’s nerve endings. The <button class='glossary-text'>hypodermis</button> (subcutaneous layer) consists of loose connective and adipose tissue.

pageData.subTitle: Cutaneous Glands
pageData.text: Cutaneous glands within the dermis include sebaceous and sweat glands. <button class='glossary-text'>Sebaceous glands</button> secrete sebum, an oily substance that waterproofs and lubricates the skin. <button class='glossary-text'>Sweat glands</button> help cool the body through evaporation of sweat.

pageData.subTitle: Fingernails
pageData.text: Fingernails and toenails are made of densely-packed cells covered in keratin. The cuticle, found at the base of the nail, provides a barrier between the skin and the nail. The body of the nail appears pink due to numerous blood vessels in the nail bed underneath. Nails protect the fingers and toes and can be used for scratching.

pageData.subTitle: Hair
pageData.text: Hair is a pigmented filament formed by mostly keratinized cells. Human hair follicles can be divided into 3 main segments: the bulb, root, and shaft. The shaft (the visible part of hair) consists of 3 layers: the cuticle, cortex, and medulla. The cortex defines texture and contains the pigment that gives hair its color.

The body is covered by skin, which provides protection from abrasion, potentially infectious microbes, and fluid loss. There are two layers of skin: the superficial <button class='glossary-text'>epidermis</button>, composed of epithelial tissue, and the deeper <button class='glossary-text'>dermis</button>, composed of connective tissue. Deep to the dermis lies another connective tissue layer, the <button class='glossary-text'>hypodermis</button>, also called the subcutaneous layer. The hypodermis is not part of the skin proper, but it is closely associated with the skin and is vital for supporting its structure and functions. An overview of the skin is shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 7</button>.

The epidermis, as seen in Figure 1, is made up of <button class='glossary-text'>stratified squamous epithelium</button>. The main characteristics of this epithelial tissue are flattened cells, also called squamous cells, that are stacked in a layered pattern. The deepest layer of epithelial cells is separated from the underlying dermis by a <button class='glossary-text'>basement membrane</button>. The basement membrane is a specialized extracellular matrix, and its main function in the skin is to anchor the epithelial layer (epidermis) to the layer of connective tissue (dermis) directly underneath.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A cross-section of the epidermis, labeled

pageData.text: The most abundant cells of the <button class='glossary-text'>epidermis</button> are the specialized epithelial cells known as <button class='glossary-text'>keratinocytes</button>. These cells are produced in the deepest region of the epidermis, and they undergo maturation as they are pushed toward the skin surface. Part of the maturation process is the production of a fibrous protein called <button class='glossary-text'>keratin</button>, which helps to make the epidermis tough and water-resistant. As keratinocytes mature, they become composed of more and more keratin protein. Their cytoplasm becomes dominated by keratin instead of functional organelles. Eventually, by the time they reach the outermost area of the epidermis, the keratinocytes have died. They are sloughed off from the surface of the epidermis, which is why replacements are continuously generated.

In thick skin, such as that on the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands, there are five layers of epidermal cells (see Figure 2). Other parts of the body that have thin skin have only four distinct layers of epidermis.

pageData.subTitle: Layers of the Epidermis
pageData.text:
1. The most superficial layer is the . Cells in this layer contain a high concentration of , making this layer tougher than the rest. Dead cells are shed from the surface of this layer.
  2. The layer just deep to the stratum corneum is the . This clear layer of cells is only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet or the palms of the hands. Cells in this layer are very densely packed and contain hardly any organelles.
  3. The next layer is the , which is characterized by cells with a granular appearance due to cytoplasmic granules.
  4. The contains cells that appear small and spiny in traditionally prepared slides due to shrinking of the cells.
  5. The deepest layer is the . This layer contains , which are a type of stem cell. This is the layer that constantly produces new epidermal cells by mitosis.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In thick skin, there are five layers of epidermal cells. Other parts of the body with thin skin have only four distinct layers of the epidermis. The most superficial layer is the stratum corneum. Cells in this layer contain a high concentration of keratin, making this layer tougher than the rest. The layer just deep to the stratum corneum is the stratum lucidum. This clear layer of cells is only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet or the palms of the hands. Cells in this layer are very densely packed and contain hardly any organelles. The next layers down are the stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum, named for the distinctive appearance of their respective cells, and the stratum basale which contains a type of stem cell responsible for producing new epidermal cells by mitosis.

pageData.subTitle: Layers of the Dermis
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>dermis</button> (see Figure 4) is made up of two distinct layers. The more superficial layer is the <button class='glossary-text'>papillary dermis</button>, which consists of areolar connective tissue. This region is characterized by fingerlike projections called <button class='glossary-text'>papillae</button>, which create folds in the <button class='glossary-text'>epidermis</button>. This layer contains blood capillaries and sensory structures (see Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A cross-section showing the two distinct layers of the dermis

pageData.text: The deeper layer of the is the . This layer is generally thicker than the papillary layer and gives the dermis strength and elasticity. This layer consists mainly of and is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers. The latter gave rise to the name reticular dermis. The overall alignment of collagenous fibers provides the skin with extra strength in a given direction. The hair and nail roots are based within this layer of the dermis and are surrounded by blood vessels. Specialized glands are also located in the reticular dermis.

<button class='glossary-text'>Sweat glands</button> (see Figure 5), also called sudoriferous glands, assist with temperature regulation. There are two types: <button class='glossary-text'>apocrine</button> sweat glands and <button class='glossary-text'>merocrine</button> (or eccrine) sweat glands. The apocrine sweat glands secrete their product directly into the hair follicles, especially in the armpits and groin. The merocrine sweat glands secrete sweat through pores directly onto the surface of the skin. They are much more numerous than apocrine sweat glands and serve a greater role in cooling the body (see Figure 6).

<button class='glossary-text'>Sebaceous glands</button> (oil glands) help keep the skin and hair flexible and water-resistant by secreting a substance called <button class='glossary-text'>sebum</button>. These glands are found throughout the skin except on the palms and soles. Some, but not all, sebaceous glands are closely associated with hair follicles. Sebum also protects the body with its bactericidal properties.

pageData.subTitle: Hypodermis
pageData.text: Deep to the is the , which connects the skin to the rest of the body. This layer is mainly made up of the loose connective areolar and . The areolar tissue contains widely spaced collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers arranged in all directions. It also contains a variety of cell types, all surrounded by abundant . Blood vessels and nerves are found throughout the hypodermis. The adipose tissue provides padding and thermal conservation for the body.

data.title: Apocrine
data.content: One of two types of sweat glands; they secrete their product directly into the hair follicles, especially in the armpits and groin

data.title: Basal cell
data.content: A type of stem cell found in the stratum basale

data.title: Basement membrane
data.content: A thin membranous layer of connective tissue that separates one layer of epithelial cells from the next

data.title: Dense irregular connective tissue
data.content: A type of connective tissue found in the dermis; it is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers

data.title: Dermis
data.content: The layer of living tissue below the epidermis

data.title: Epidermis
data.content: The surface tissue layer of the skin

data.title: Ground substance
data.content: A component of ECM made up of mostly water with added polysaccharide and protein molecules for stability

data.title: Hypodermis
data.content: The connective tissue layer deep to the dermis; although not part of the skin proper, it is closely associated with the skin and is vital for supporting its structure and function; also called the subcutaneous layer

data.title: Keratin
data.content: A fibrous protein that helps to make the epidermis tough and water-resistant

data.title: Keratinocytes
data.content: The most abundant cells of the epidermis; they are specialized epithelial cells produced in the deepest region of the epidermis, and which undergo maturation as they are pushed toward the skin surface

data.title: Merocrine
data.content: One of two types of sweat glands that secrete sweat through pores directly onto the surface of the skin; also called eccrine

data.title: Papillae
data.content: Fingerlike projections in the papillary dermis that increase the strength of the connection between the epidermis and dermis

data.title: Papillary dermis
data.content: The more superficial of the two layers of the dermis; it consists of areolar connective tissue

data.title: Reticular dermis
data.content: The deeper of the two layers of the dermis; it is generally thicker than the papillary dermis, and gives the dermis strength and elasticity

data.title: Sebaceous glands
data.content: Oil glands that help keep the skin and hair flexible and water-resistant

data.title: Sebum
data.content: The water-resistant substance secreted by sebaceous glands; it also has bactericidal properties

data.title: Stratified squamous epithelium
data.content: A type of epithelial tissue made up of several layers of cells that are roughly cuboidal at the base of the epithelium, but go on to become progressively more flattened as they form the surface of the tissue; it makes up the epidermis

data.title: Stratum basale
data.content: The deepest layer of the epidermis

data.title: Stratum corneum
data.content: The most superficial layer of the epidermis

data.title: Stratum granulosum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum lucidum and which is made up of cells with a granular appearance due to cytoplasmic granules

data.title: Stratum lucidum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum corneum, and which is a clear layer of cells only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands

data.title: Stratum spinosum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum granulosum, and which contains cells that appear small and spiny in traditionally prepared slides due to shrinking of the cells

data.title: Sweat glands
data.content: Glands in the skin that assist with temperature regulation via product secretion; also called sudoriferous glands
